name: Chile
partner: Andrés Bello Foundation – Latin American Chinese Research Center
takeaway: China has increased its influence efforts in Chile, regaining lost connections that were the result of the pandemic and efforts to counter related global criticism. This has been achieved by utilizing local partners and renaming institutions and projects. The current Chinese ambassador in Chile has followed the international guidance of behaviour and action, but is less aggressive than his predecesor. Chinese influence in Chile observed by the Index has increased since the last assessment, in 2021.

New evidence suggests Chinese involvement in sovereignity and crime-related issues is greater than previously thought, and examples of this include cases of international drug and human trafficking rings, attempts to falsify origin certification in products, or the presence of overseas police stations.

In most aspects, the relationship between Chilean authorities and the PRC remains friendly, with few controversies that have a national impact but have only impacted specific sectors. Elite relations are not limited to political ideology or international positioning, and many parliamentary members or authorities have defended China, even when it comes to human rights issues. Since the economic relations are strong, notable businesspeople are often linked to the PRC and defend the system.

Chile has mildly increased its security debate regarding China, in areas such as technology and strategic economic endevours, with both supporters and detractors at a national level. Related issues include 5G connections or optic fiber connections. Also regarding science and Antartic affairs. Academia has remained largely neutral on the matter, with exceptions.

The CCP has found ways to capitalize on the media connections it has built over the years rather than pushing to establish connections with all media outlets. In a private capacity, journalists have mentioned feeling pressured, but have been protected by the country's press freedom. As a result, a selective group of likeminded journalists have been utilized to disseminate PRC narratives instead.
description-1: In 2023, Chile had a GDP per capita of US$17,093 and a total population of 19.6 million people.
description-2: Chile established full diplomatic relations with the People's Republic of China in 1970. Chile was ranked 52nd in Reporters Without Borders‘ 2024 World Press Freedom Index, and rated Free in Freedom House‘s 2024 Global Freedom Index, with a score of 94/100.

Media.evidence: Only few examples of this happening, with clear evidence of the PRC paying for said trips and with sensible credibility is limited, therefore this indicator deserves a " few" rating. Nevertheless, the impact of these paid trips is significant. A clear example of this happening, since there are public records, is journalist Fabian Pizzaro from Radio Cooperativa, who has claimed to have been invited to China in several ocasions, writes papers and Op-eds praising the Chinese system and describes the nature of his paid-trips to China. Other cases include jounalists from Xinhua, or María Sanhueza who is a journalist for El Ciudadano, and travelled to China, where she promoted the Belt and Road initiative and was featured in a press release by the Chinese MOFA account in instagram, Another example is the president of the Press Club or Journalism Union, who visited China with a municipal delegation in 2023.

Media.evidence: As for owned by the CCP: Some Chinese organizations such as the Trade Chamber of Chilean and Chinese affairs (CHICIT) run magazines or radio programs in which they disseminate their work and views. Nevertheless, these outlets have limited distribution and are mostly private. The only exception of a further dissemination attempts is the Observatorio Asia Pacífico from the The National Library of the Chilean Congress, which has developed some agreements to hold these materials and share them. Therefore, this indicator deserves a "few" rating. As for business interests in the RPC: the Luksic group is both involved with China in different levels and owns several media outlets including radio groups and Tele-13. Indirectly, Radio cooperativa has interests through the legacy of Eduardo Frei Ruiz-Tagle, as the conglomerate that owns the radio is closely related to the Democracia Cristiana and donated money to their candidates. Ruiz-Tagle is the current Chilean commercial envoy to Asia and the president that kickstarted the FTA with China.  Therefore, this indicator deserves a "significant" rating.

Media.evidence: Several of the country's most popular media outlets published content provided by the CCP in the last five years.  The China Media Group or Grupo de Medios de China pays for assigned spaces and alliances with media.Therefore, this indicator deserves a "more than a few" rating. A short-lived example was Conexión China, which is out of the paywall of La Tercera. Although it was discontinued in 2020 it is still online. radio Cooperativa's Efecto China is the most significant running example, with news reposted directly from Chinese Media such as the Global Times. Finally, an interview with the CMG in EMOL TV is suspected to be paid content because the platform it was published in is known to charge for special editions. Therefore, this indicator deserves a "significant" rating.

Media.evidence: Media in Chile would rather choose to be neutral, aside from their editorial line which guides the use of terminology for specific affairs. I was never compelled to use a specific terminology as a journalist when working at newspapers. China is referred to "Chile's main economic partner", and terms such "the asian giant" or "the power of the east" are conciously avoided outside of the aforementioned paid reportages or inserts which do use this terminology. The exception to this seems to be Radio Cooperativa, in which the existence of a paid agreement is likely to permeate their editorial guidelines. Almost all publications by this outlet on China are in alliance with the CMG. Therefore, this indicator deserves an "few, insignificant" rating.

At the end, the president signed an agreement with China abiding by their position on development. Therefore, this indicator deserves a "few" but "significant" rating.

Academia.evidence: Some of Chile’s main universities have established partnerships with Chinese companies and also the Chinese embassy. It includes but is not limited to: University of Chile, which has partnerships with Huawei; INACAP; which signed an alliance with BYD; Universidad de Concepción which has several programs with China or Universidad Austral, which also signed collaboration agreements and has been featured in the Chinese embassy webpage. Therefore this indicator deserves a "More than a few" rating. It is important to clarify that this is something that is also done with western companies such as Amazon.  Therefore this indicator deserves a "Significant" rating.
Academia.note: Since the release of the last report, Universidad de Chile took down the link of some events remarking their collaboration with DiDi and Huawei. https://www.facebook.com/uchile/posts/10158774654262040/ (Backup)

Academia.evidence: There are three well established Confucius institutes in Chile, as well as the regional center for Language Teaching CLEC (Previously known as CRICAL or the regional office for Confucius Institutes in Latin America). Other local organizations, like fundación Cruzando el pacífico, also cooperate with the Chinese embassy to provide chinese classes in coordination with some confucius institutes.  Therefore this indicator deserves a "more than a few" and "Significant" rating.
Academia.note: CRICAL, the regional office for Latin American confucius institutes, and which webpage was "https://www.crical.cl/" now redirects to https://fundacionclec.org/, which expresses its connection with the Chinese Education Ministry and that dircted towards the Latin American public. It has severed its relation with the confucius institutes, but is codirected by Roberto Lafontaine, who is closely related with the Universidad Santo Tomás Confucius Institute.
Academia.answerer: Answered by 1 anonymous expert, and has been reviewed by another 1 anonymous expert.

Academia.evidence: In 2018, 16 schools from 5 regions of the country received Chinese language education a direct product of a MOA between the Chile and the Chinese Ministries of education. The pandemic and economic crisis has dramatically reduced these schools to only 9, but more than 10,000 students were benefited from the program up to 2017. These students were encourage to certify their language habilities through official tests. Universidad Católica also conducts a yearly contest with the Chinese embassy and the Confucious Institute to send one student to China after competing with their Chinese abilities. Other estimates published by the Chinese Media Group on an Insert paid to El Mercurio on 2021 claimed that up to 1,000,000 chileans had studied in their programs.  More examples can be found in repositories such as the National Congress Library 2020 cooperation report. Therefore this indicator deserves a "Yes" response.
Academia.note: Since the influence of this program still exists but has been hindered, I would advice for a decrease on the score given to this index. It does not deserve 0 or 4 points.
Academia.answerer: Answered by 1 anonymous expert, and has been reviewed by another 1 anonymous expert.

Academia.evidence: The Chinese Academy of Sciences South America Center for Astronomy (Cassaca) operates in the country since 2013 and has several projects running in the area of astronomical research, as well as helding programs and seminars in China. On top of that, they have launched several calls for joint research. Secondly, The Luksic Scholars' Association, an organization funded by one of Chile's wealthiest families (Luksic), was instrumental in the foundation of Tsinghua University's regional research center in Chile, and cooperates in funding for scholarships in China. The same university has also sought to increase their parnerships. Since these Chinese institutions are directly linked to Chilean organizations such as local universities and the Chilean government, they have been added to this entry.  In 2021, the second CELAC-China academic forum included the VI China-Lac Think tanks forum. This event included Ambassador Niu Qingbao and the support of the Chilean state, where the CELAC (ECLAC) headquarters are located. Therefore this indicator deserves a "Significant" rating.
Academia.note: The mentioned research centers are not listed in the provided links but they exist and operate in Chilean soil, as well as finance paid trips to China and training programs for young researchers. Nevertheless, they are nor widely talked about in the Chilean sphere.

Academia.evidence: Most academics on China try to keep a neutral position when it comes to human rights and the country's development, and therefore they concentrate their efforts in historic, cultural or economic matters. When touching upon the issue, academics and students would also maintain (generally) a neutral position, even if they have connections with Chinese organizations. Nevertheless, exceptions are notable, and this indicator deserves a "few" rating. Jorge Heine is a former ambassador to China and also an academic who is part of a Chinese Studies program at Universidad de Chile and at the Boston University, US. He has rutinely defended the Chinese system, and recently published a book on Xi Jinping claims such as: "centering the debate around Human Rights does not help" and calling the Xinjiang camps "de-radicalization" campaigns. Since there is an open debate on the issue and other academics actually criticize China's Human Rights record, this indicator deserves an "insignificant" rating.
Academia.note: We also found evidence of several academics defending the need to condemn Human Rights violations in China, like the following op-ed by a Universidad Central professor: https://radio.ucentral.cl/columnas/ningun-estado-puede-eludir-la-obligacion-de-respetar-los-derechos-humanos/
Academia.answerer: Answered by 1 anonymous expert, and has been reviewed by another 1 anonymous expert.
